» DAILY BULLETIN... DAILY BULLETIN... DAILY BULLETIN...

.-PUBLIC AFFAIRS DIVISION... THE TOBACCO INSTITUTE...

WEDNESDAY

JUNE 25, 1997

IN REVIEW.IN REVIEW...

Today, the U.S. HOUSE Agriculture/FDA Subemte reported a $13.6 billion FY9S

spending bill for the FDA. The Subcmie apprupriatcd $15.2 million for FDA enforcement

of the first phase of the tobacco regulations... FDA had requested $34 million.

The U.S, SENATE Judiciary Cmte will begin a series of hearings tomorrow to review the

terms of the agreement between the State Atlorncys General and the tobaceo indusiry...a

hearing on the agreement's legal implications is set for 7/16 and another on public health

issues for 7/30, Mississippi Atomey General Moore and National Center for Tobaceo-

Public Affairs Division - The Tobacco Institute - 1875 E Street, NW - Washington, DC 20006
November 19, 1998

HEADLINES

+ Atanews conference on 11/16, Attorneys General for sex eral states including Washington,

Pennsyl ania, OMahoma, North Dakota, New York, and Colorado announced and released a proposed
settlement agreement with tobacco companies, stating the settlement “moves the fight out of the
courtroom and onto the streets so we can begin protecting kids now.” Under the $206 billion
setement proposal, tobacco companies would agree to “curbs on their advertising and marketing
campaigns, fund a $1.5 billion anti-smoking campaign, open previously secret industry documents, and
disband industry trade groups,” including The Tobacco Institute, Council for Tobacca Research, and
Council for Indoor Air Research. Attorncys General for the remaining states have until Friday to sign
on to the agreement.

+ The full U.S Fourth Circuit Court of Appeals denied on LIL EDA’s request to re hear the August 14
decision of a three-judge panel of the Court which ruled that PDA does not have the authority to
regulate cigarettes or smokeless tobacco, “The Clinton Administration plans to appeal the decision to
the U.S. Supreme Court.

+ Rob Reiner, chair of the Prop. 10 campaign announced on LI/E) that the California Children and
Families Initiative had been approved by voters, stating, “California voters saw through Big Tobacco’s
smokescreen and voted to improve the future of California's children rather than protecting tobacco
company’s profits.” The Committee Against Unfair Taxes acknowledged “that they do nat have
enough absentee vates to overcome the current deficit.” Prop. 10 increases the tobacco tax by 50 cents
per pack to fund children's health care and early childhood development programs, effective 1/1/99.

+ New York Attorney General Race Update, Manhattan Assistant District Attorney Spitzer is scheduled
to make a public announcement today to declare victory over incumbent New York Attorney General
Vacco. ‘The latest numbers show Spitzer holding a 22,600-vote lead with fewer than 20,000 paper
ballots to be counted.
